section.names: instructions\ for\ setting\ up\ a\ development\ vm
section.title: Instructions for setting up a development VM
section.paragraph: This section documents setting up a virtual machine for doing Swift development. The virtual machine will emulate running a four node Swift cluster. To begin:

list_item.paragraph: Get an Ubuntu 14.04 LTS server image or try something Fedora/CentOS.
Create guest virtual machine from the image.

section.title: What’s in a <your-user-name>
section.paragraph: Much of the configuration described in this guide requires escalated administrator (root) privileges; however, we assume that administrator logs in as an unprivileged user and can use sudo to run privileged commands.

Swift processes also run under a separate user and group, set by configuration option, and referenced as <your-user-name>:<your-group-name>. The default user is swift, which may not exist on your system. These instructions are intended to allow a developer to use his/her username for <your-user-name>:<your-group-name>.

section.title: Installing dependencies

list_item.paragraph: On apt based systems:
list_item.literal_block: sudo apt-get update sudo apt-get install curl gcc memcached rsync sqlite3 xfsprogs \ git-core libffi-dev python-setuptools \ liberasurecode-dev libssl-dev sudo apt-get install python-coverage python-dev python-nose \ python-xattr python-eventlet \ python-greenlet python-pastedeploy \ python-netifaces python-pip python-dnspython \ python-mock

list_item.paragraph: On yum based systems:
list_item.literal_block: sudo yum update sudo yum install curl gcc memcached rsync sqlite xfsprogs git-core \ libffi-devel xinetd liberasurecode-devel \ openssl-devel python-setuptools \ python-coverage python-devel python-nose \ pyxattr python-eventlet \ python-greenlet python-paste-deploy \ python-netifaces python-pip python-dns \ python-mock
list_item.paragraph: Note: This installs necessary system dependencies and most of the python dependencies. Later in the process setuptools/distribute or pip will install and/or upgrade packages.

section.paragraph: Next, choose either Using a partition for storage or Using a loopback device for storage.

section.names: using\ a\ partition\ for\ storage partition-section
section.title: Using a partition for storage
section.paragraph: If you are going to use a separate partition for Swift data, be sure to add another device when creating the VM, and follow these instructions:

list_item.paragraph: Set up a single partition:
list_item.literal_block: sudo fdisk /dev/sdb sudo mkfs.xfs /dev/sdb1

list_item.paragraph: Edit /etc/fstab and add:
list_item.literal_block: /dev/sdb1 /mnt/sdb1 xfs noatime,nodiratime,nobarrier,logbufs=8 0 0

list_item.paragraph: Create the mount point and the individualized links:
list_item.literal_block: sudo mkdir /mnt/sdb1 sudo mount /mnt/sdb1 sudo mkdir /mnt/sdb1/1 /mnt/sdb1/2 /mnt/sdb1/3 /mnt/sdb1/4 sudo chown ${USER}:${USER} /mnt/sdb1/* sudo mkdir /srv for x in {1..4}; do sudo ln -s /mnt/sdb1/$x /srv/$x; done sudo mkdir -p /srv/1/node/sdb1 /srv/1/node/sdb5 \ /srv/2/node/sdb2 /srv/2/node/sdb6 \ /srv/3/node/sdb3 /srv/3/node/sdb7 \ /srv/4/node/sdb4 /srv/4/node/sdb8 \ /var/run/swift sudo chown -R ${USER}:${USER} /var/run/swift # **Make sure to include the trailing slash after /srv/$x/** for x in {1..4}; do sudo chown -R ${USER}:${USER} /srv/$x/; done
list_item.paragraph: Note: We create the mount points and mount the storage disk under /mnt/sdb1. This disk will contain one directory per simulated swift node, each owned by the current swift user.

We then create symlinks to these directories under /srv. If the disk sdb is unmounted, files will not be written under /srv/*, because the symbolic link destination /mnt/sdb1/* will not exist. This prevents disk sync operations from writing to the root partition in the event a drive is unmounted.
Next, skip to Common Post-Device Setup.

section.names: using\ a\ loopback\ device\ for\ storage loopback-section
section.title: Using a loopback device for storage
section.paragraph: If you want to use a loopback device instead of another partition, follow these instructions:

list_item.paragraph: Create the file for the loopback device:
list_item.literal_block: sudo mkdir /srv sudo truncate -s 1GB /srv/swift-disk sudo mkfs.xfs /srv/swift-disk
list_item.paragraph: Modify size specified in the truncate command to make a larger or smaller partition as needed.
Edit /etc/fstab and add:
list_item.literal_block: /srv/swift-disk /mnt/sdb1 xfs loop,noatime,nodiratime,nobarrier,logbufs=8 0 0

list_item.paragraph: Create the mount point and the individualized links:
list_item.literal_block: sudo mkdir /mnt/sdb1 sudo mount /mnt/sdb1 sudo mkdir /mnt/sdb1/1 /mnt/sdb1/2 /mnt/sdb1/3 /mnt/sdb1/4 sudo chown ${USER}:${USER} /mnt/sdb1/* for x in {1..4}; do sudo ln -s /mnt/sdb1/$x /srv/$x; done sudo mkdir -p /srv/1/node/sdb1 /srv/1/node/sdb5 \ /srv/2/node/sdb2 /srv/2/node/sdb6 \ /srv/3/node/sdb3 /srv/3/node/sdb7 \ /srv/4/node/sdb4 /srv/4/node/sdb8 \ /var/run/swift sudo chown -R ${USER}:${USER} /var/run/swift # **Make sure to include the trailing slash after /srv/$x/** for x in {1..4}; do sudo chown -R ${USER}:${USER} /srv/$x/; done
list_item.paragraph: Note: We create the mount points and mount the loopback file under /mnt/sdb1. This file will contain one directory per simulated swift node, each owned by the current swift user.

We then create symlinks to these directories under /srv. If the loopback file is unmounted, files will not be written under /srv/*, because the symbolic link destination /mnt/sdb1/* will not exist. This prevents disk sync operations from writing to the root partition in the event a drive is unmounted.

section.title: Common Post-Device Setup
section.paragraph: Add the following lines to /etc/rc.local (before the exit 0):
Note that on some systems you might have to create /etc/rc.local.
On Fedora 19 or later, you need to place these in /etc/rc.d/rc.local.

list_item.paragraph: Check out the python-swiftclient repo:
list_item.literal_block: cd $HOME; git clone https://github.com/openstack/python-swiftclient.git

list_item.paragraph: Build a development installation of python-swiftclient:
list_item.literal_block: cd $HOME/python-swiftclient; sudo python setup.py develop; cd -
list_item.paragraph: Ubuntu 12.04 users need to install python-swiftclient’s dependencies before the installation of python-swiftclient. This is due to a bug in an older version of setup tools:
list_item.literal_block: cd $HOME/python-swiftclient; sudo pip install -r requirements.txt; sudo python setup.py develop; cd -

list_item.paragraph: Check out the swift repo:
list_item.literal_block: git clone https://github.com/openstack/swift.git

list_item.paragraph: Build a development installation of swift:
list_item.literal_block: cd $HOME/swift; sudo pip install -r requirements.txt; sudo python setup.py develop; cd -
list_item.paragraph: Fedora 19 or later users might have to perform the following if development installation of swift fails:
list_item.literal_block: sudo pip install -U xattr

list_item.paragraph: Install swift’s test dependencies:
list_item.literal_block: cd $HOME/swift; sudo pip install -r test-requirements.txt

list_item.paragraph: Create /etc/rsyncd.conf:
list_item.literal_block: sudo cp $HOME/swift/doc/saio/rsyncd.conf /etc/ sudo sed -i "s/<your-user-name>/${USER}/" /etc/rsyncd.conf
list_item.paragraph: Here is the default rsyncd.conf file contents maintained in the repo that is copied and fixed up above:
list_item.literal_block:
uid = <your-user-name> gid = <your-user-name> log file = /var/log/rsyncd.log pid file = /var/run/rsyncd.pid address = 0.0.0.0
[account6012] max connections = 25 path = /srv/1/node/ read only = false lock file = /var/lock/account6012.lock
[account6022] max connections = 25 path = /srv/2/node/ read only = false lock file = /var/lock/account6022.lock
[account6032] max connections = 25 path = /srv/3/node/ read only = false lock file = /var/lock/account6032.lock
[account6042] max connections = 25 path = /srv/4/node/ read only = false lock file = /var/lock/account6042.lock
[container6011] max connections = 25 path = /srv/1/node/ read only = false lock file = /var/lock/container6011.lock
[container6021] max connections = 25 path = /srv/2/node/ read only = false lock file = /var/lock/container6021.lock
[container6031] max connections = 25 path = /srv/3/node/ read only = false lock file = /var/lock/container6031.lock
[container6041] max connections = 25 path = /srv/4/node/ read only = false lock file = /var/lock/container6041.lock
[object6010] max connections = 25 path = /srv/1/node/ read only = false lock file = /var/lock/object6010.lock
[object6020] max connections = 25 path = /srv/2/node/ read only = false lock file = /var/lock/object6020.lock
[object6030] max connections = 25 path = /srv/3/node/ read only = false lock file = /var/lock/object6030.lock
[object6040] max connections = 25 path = /srv/4/node/ read only = false lock file = /var/lock/object6040.lock

list_item.paragraph: On Ubuntu, edit the following line in /etc/default/rsync:
list_item.literal_block: RSYNC_ENABLE=true
list_item.paragraph: On Fedora, edit the following line in /etc/xinetd.d/rsync:
list_item.literal_block: disable = no
list_item.paragraph: One might have to create the above files to perform the edits.
On platforms with SELinux in Enforcing mode, either set to Permissive:
list_item.literal_block: sudo setenforce Permissive
list_item.paragraph: Or just allow rsync full access:
list_item.literal_block: sudo setsebool -P rsync_full_access 1

list_item.paragraph: Start the rsync daemon
On Ubuntu 14.04, run:
list_item.literal_block: sudo service rsync restart

list_item.paragraph: On Ubuntu 16.04, run:
list_item.literal_block: sudo systemctl enable rsync sudo systemctl start rsync

list_item.paragraph: On Fedora, run:
list_item.literal_block: sudo systemctl restart xinetd.service sudo systemctl enable rsyncd.service sudo systemctl start rsyncd.service

list_item.paragraph: On other xinetd based systems simply run:
list_item.literal_block: sudo service xinetd restart

list_item.paragraph: Verify rsync is accepting connections for all servers:
list_item.literal_block: rsync rsync://pub@localhost/
list_item.paragraph: You should see the following output from the above command:
list_item.literal_block: account6012 account6022 account6032 account6042 container6011 container6021 container6031 container6041 object6010 object6020 object6030 object6040

section.title: Starting memcached
section.paragraph: On non-Ubuntu distros you need to ensure memcached is running:
section.literal_block: sudo service memcached start sudo chkconfig memcached on
sudo systemctl enable memcached.service sudo systemctl start memcached.service
section.paragraph: The tempauth middleware stores tokens in memcached. If memcached is not running, tokens cannot be validated, and accessing Swift becomes impossible.

section.names: optional:\ setting\ up\ rsyslog\ for\ individual\ logging
section.title: Optional: Setting up rsyslog for individual logging

list_item.paragraph: Install the swift rsyslogd configuration:
list_item.literal_block: sudo cp $HOME/swift/doc/saio/rsyslog.d/10-swift.conf /etc/rsyslog.d/
list_item.paragraph: Be sure to review that conf file to determine if you want all the logs in one file vs. all the logs separated out, and if you want hourly logs for stats processing. For convenience, we provide its default contents below:
list_item.literal_block:
# Uncomment the following to have a log containing all logs together #local1,local2,local3,local4,local5.* /var/log/swift/all.log
# Uncomment the following to have hourly proxy logs for stats processing #$template HourlyProxyLog,"/var/log/swift/hourly/%$YEAR%%$MONTH%%$DAY%%$HOUR%" #local1.*;local1.!notice ?HourlyProxyLog
local1.*;local1.!notice /var/log/swift/proxy.log local1.notice /var/log/swift/proxy.error local1.* ~
local2.*;local2.!notice /var/log/swift/storage1.log local2.notice /var/log/swift/storage1.error local2.* ~
local3.*;local3.!notice /var/log/swift/storage2.log local3.notice /var/log/swift/storage2.error local3.* ~
local4.*;local4.!notice /var/log/swift/storage3.log local4.notice /var/log/swift/storage3.error local4.* ~
local5.*;local5.!notice /var/log/swift/storage4.log local5.notice /var/log/swift/storage4.error local5.* ~
local6.*;local6.!notice /var/log/swift/expirer.log local6.notice /var/log/swift/expirer.error local6.* ~

list_item.paragraph: Edit /etc/rsyslog.conf and make the following change (usually in the “GLOBAL DIRECTIVES” section):
list_item.literal_block: $PrivDropToGroup adm

list_item.paragraph: If using hourly logs (see above) perform:
list_item.literal_block: sudo mkdir -p /var/log/swift/hourly
list_item.paragraph: Otherwise perform:
list_item.literal_block: sudo mkdir -p /var/log/swift

list_item.paragraph: Setup the logging directory and start syslog:
On Ubuntu:
list_item.literal_block: sudo chown -R syslog.adm /var/log/swift sudo chmod -R g+w /var/log/swift sudo service rsyslog restart

list_item.paragraph: On Fedora:
list_item.literal_block: sudo chown -R root:adm /var/log/swift sudo chmod -R g+w /var/log/swift sudo systemctl restart rsyslog.service

section.title: Configuring each node
section.paragraph: After performing the following steps, be sure to verify that Swift has access to resulting configuration files (sample configuration files are provided with all defaults in line-by-line comments).

list_item.paragraph: Optionally remove an existing swift directory:
list_item.literal_block: sudo rm -rf /etc/swift

list_item.paragraph: Populate the /etc/swift directory itself:
list_item.literal_block: cd $HOME/swift/doc; sudo cp -r saio/swift /etc/swift; cd - sudo chown -R ${USER}:${USER} /etc/swift

list_item.paragraph: Update <your-user-name> references in the Swift config files:
list_item.literal_block: find /etc/swift/ -name \*.conf | xargs sudo sed -i "s/<your-user-name>/${USER}/"

section.names: setting\ up\ scripts\ for\ running\ swift setup_scripts
section.title: Setting up scripts for running Swift

list_item.paragraph: Copy the SAIO scripts for resetting the environment:
list_item.literal_block: mkdir -p $HOME/bin cd $HOME/swift/doc; cp saio/bin/* $HOME/bin; cd - chmod +x $HOME/bin/*

list_item.paragraph: Edit the $HOME/bin/resetswift script
The template resetswift script looks like the following:
If you are using a loopback device add an environment var to substitute /dev/sdb1 with /srv/swift-disk:
list_item.literal_block: echo "export SAIO_BLOCK_DEVICE=/srv/swift-disk" >> $HOME/.bashrc
list_item.paragraph: If you did not set up rsyslog for individual logging, remove the find /var/log/swift... line:
list_item.literal_block: sed -i "/find \/var\/log\/swift/d" $HOME/bin/resetswift

list_item.paragraph: Install the sample configuration file for running tests:
list_item.literal_block: cp $HOME/swift/test/sample.conf /etc/swift/test.conf
list_item.paragraph: The template test.conf looks like the following:

block_quote.literal_block:

list_item.paragraph: Add an environment variable for running tests below:
list_item.literal_block: echo "export SWIFT_TEST_CONFIG_FILE=/etc/swift/test.conf" >> $HOME/.bashrc

list_item.paragraph: Be sure that your PATH includes the bin directory:
list_item.literal_block: echo "export PATH=${PATH}:$HOME/bin" >> $HOME/.bashrc

list_item.paragraph: Source the above environment variables into your current environment:
list_item.literal_block: . $HOME/.bashrc

list_item.literal_block: remakerings

list_item.paragraph: Read more about Storage Policies and your SAIO Adding Storage Policies to an Existing SAIO
Verify the unit tests run:
list_item.literal_block: $HOME/swift/.unittests
list_item.paragraph: Note that the unit tests do not require any swift daemons running.
Start the “main” Swift daemon processes (proxy, account, container, and object):
list_item.literal_block: startmain
list_item.paragraph: (The “Unable to increase file descriptor limit. Running as non-root?” warnings are expected and ok.)
The startmain script looks like the following:
Get an X-Storage-Url and X-Auth-Token:
list_item.literal_block: curl -v -H 'X-Storage-User: test:tester' -H 'X-Storage-Pass: testing' http://127.0.0.1:8080/auth/v1.0

list_item.paragraph: Check that you can GET account:
list_item.literal_block: curl -v -H 'X-Auth-Token: <token-from-x-auth-token-above>' <url-from-x-storage-url-above>

list_item.paragraph: Check that swift command provided by the python-swiftclient package works:
list_item.literal_block: swift -A http://127.0.0.1:8080/auth/v1.0 -U test:tester -K testing stat

list_item.paragraph: Verify the functional tests run:
list_item.literal_block: $HOME/swift/.functests
list_item.paragraph: (Note: functional tests will first delete everything in the configured accounts.)
Verify the probe tests run:
list_item.literal_block: $HOME/swift/.probetests
list_item.paragraph: (Note: probe tests will reset your environment as they call resetswift for each test.)

section.title: Debugging Issues
section.paragraph: If all doesn’t go as planned, and tests fail, or you can’t auth, or something doesn’t work, here are some good starting places to look for issues:

list_item.paragraph: Everything is logged using system facilities – usually in /var/log/syslog, but possibly in /var/log/messages on e.g. Fedora – so that is a good first place to look for errors (most likely python tracebacks).
Make sure all of the server processes are running. For the base functionality, the Proxy, Account, Container, and Object servers should be running.

If one of the servers are not running, and no errors are logged to syslog, it may be useful to try to start the server manually, for example: swift-object-server /etc/swift/object-server/1.conf will start the object server. If there are problems not showing up in syslog, then you will likely see the traceback on startup.

If you need to, you can turn off syslog for unit tests. This can be useful for environments where /dev/log is unavailable, or which cannot rate limit (unit tests generate a lot of logs very quickly). Open the file SWIFT_TEST_CONFIG_FILE points to, and change the value of fake_syslog to True.

If you encounter a 401 Unauthorized when following Step 12 where you check that you can GET account, use sudo service memcached status and check if memcache is running. If memcache is not running, start it using sudo service memcached start. Once memcache is running, rerun GET account.

section.title: Known Issues
section.paragraph: Listed here are some “gotcha’s” that you may run into when using or testing your SAIO:

list_item.paragraph: fallocate_reserve - in most cases a SAIO doesn’t have a very large XFS partition so having fallocate enabled and fallocate_reserve set can cause issues, specifically when trying to run the functional tests. For this reason fallocate has been turned off on the object-servers in the SAIO. If you want to play with the fallocate_reserve settings then know that functional tests will fail unless you change the max_file_size constraint to something more reasonable then the default (5G). Ideally you’d make it 1/4 of your XFS file system size so the tests can pass.
